data.text: Contents
Introduction

This document provides a strategic framework for the delivery and development of Library and Knowledge Services (LKS) at Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSEFT) for the year 2021/22. This is an interim strategy because it is planned to have a formal consultation regarding the merging of the management of the three MSEFT libraries.

“NHS Bodies, their staff, learners, patients and the public use the right knowledge and evidence, at the right time, in the right place, enabling high quality decision- making, learning, research and innovation to achieve excellent healthcare and health improvement”
The Secretary of State for Health has a duty, under the Health and Social Care Act 2012, to ensure “the use in the health service of evidence obtained from research”i.

NHS Library & Knowledge Services (LKS) have a key role in enabling NHS staff and students to have access to and use appropriate knowledge to support their practice of evidence-based care, their learning and development and their research

LKS are overseen by Health Education England, which has published policies relating to services, chief of which is Knowledge for Healthcare – A Development Framework for Library and Knowledge Services-2015-2020ii. This is about to be superseded by a 2021-2026 iterationiii. Guiding principles of the HEE LKS vision remain as below and are central to the creation of this strategy

NHS Libraries are subject to the Quality and Improvement Outcomes Framework for NHS Funded Library and Knowledge Services in England, 2019. These standards specify the Library should have a board approved Library Service Strategy (Appendix 1)
Purpose
The purpose of the library strategy is to:

To advance excellence in the Trust and our partner organisations by delivering the best library and knowledge services possible, providing professional knowledge and evidence based resources to enhance patient care and safety.
To promote the understanding and practice of evidence based healthcare for all staff, patients and the public, thus contributing to health improvement and well-being across Essex communities.
Definitions

table_items.text: Work in partnership and across boundaries; pooling resources to optimise impact
Streamline management, System and process; achieve value for money
Equity of access and opportunity; meeting accessibility standards
Flexibility, new models of service, best practice
Benefits to patients; high performing; continually improving; evaluated outcomes; a positive impact
Changing working practice; contributing to a low-carbon society
Harnessing technology to continually improve services
Developing a diverse and inclusive, skilled, flexible

data.text: Background /local context

The libraries at Basildon and Broomfield sit within the People and Organisational Development Directorate. The library at Southend sits within Medical Education, under  the  Corporate  Medical  Directorate.  The  libraries  are  primarily  funded  by Health Education England working across the East of England (HEE EoE). There are formal contracts to provide services to Essex Partnership Foundation Trust (EPUT) and Pathology First (PF) including the procurement and maintenance of all e-resources. There are informal agreements with other Trust and Organisations including NELFT and local hospices. The LKS supports MSE and EPUT students (medical, clinical and non-clinical) whilst on placement.
The Broomfield library is underused compared to Basildon and that is a key issue to be addressed within this strategy
LKS  staff  also  work  closely  with  other  NHS  LKS  colleagues  in  other  regions, especially the East of England with particular reference to those in Essex
Current resources and services
Staff

The three sites are managed by three professionally qualified and chartered librarians who are supported by professionally qualified Assistant Librarians at Basildon and Southend. All sites have staffing in place , with a combination of professionally qualified staff and paraprofessional staff covering a possible user base of approximately 15,000 WTE staff.
Book Stock

The library stock comprises of approximately 17,800 (7,800+ at Basildon, 2,700 at MEHT and 7,300 at Southend) covering all aspects of working in healthcare. The stock at Broomfield is currently being assessed. Users may borrow up to eight books at a time. Users have access to the collections of all the East of England regional libraries via the ELMS OPAC. Users have access to a collection of locally purchased e-books plus 1,000+ in ClinicalKey.
Journals

Current journal titles are supplied in electronic format and purchased appropriate to the needs of the user groups. Usage of the journal stock is monitored and input from users is sought prior to the placing of annual subscription orders. Users have access to 600+ full text titles in ClinicalKey and 2,000+ via NICE Evidence national resources website.
Catalogue

The Library is part of and has access to the East of England Library Management System ELMS. Details of holdings are available to all NHS staff in the region. Users can also place holds on books; renew their loans and request books and articles from other libraries as well as literature searches
Web Presence

The Basildon library has its own website BTUHEKS which can be accessed via Trust intranets and externally. This links to the ELMS catalogue, our electronic resources and all the NHS e-resources. There are links to external sites which would be useful to healthcare staff as well as other helpful information and links. The website is seen as the focus of marketing activity. Managers have organized a new web presence for Broomfield on the new MSE Trust website.
Southend has a web presence on the Southend Hospital external website. A key aspect will be to provide one overarching web presence for the whole of MSEFT libraries in the near future.
Resources via NHS Athens

Staff have access, via NHS Open Athens, to a wide range of electronic resources, locally, regionally and nationally purchased. Library Assistants administer Athens accounts for MSEFT and EPUT. Basildon, Broomfield and Southend have recently been moved to one MSEFT NHS Athens administrative account. The library has purchased resources appropriate for medical education such as OnExamination, RCP CPD Online and point of care resources for evidence based patient care such as UpToDate and ClinicalKey.
Interlending

The libraries belong to various collaborative schemes both regional and national including the British Library to acquire requested material not in our stock. Users have access to the stock of all the libraries in the East of England via the regional catalogue.
Computers
All sites provide access to networked computers for Trust staff. All sites allow 24/7 access to computers. NHS Wi-Fi service is available in the libraries.
Study space and Facilities

Basildon library provides quiet study space and areas for both individual and group study. Soft furnishings are also supplied so users can read and relax in the well- being area. The library has a printer and two scanners to allow for easy access to material which may not be taken out of the library. Printing if free.

Broomfield library environment includes a training room upstairs with computers and a small number of PCs downstairs. There is currently no specific well-being area and the space to study and relax has been identified as less conducive that the space at Basildon.

Southend library provides quiet study space and areas for individual and group study. Soft furnishings are also available so users can relax. The library has black and white and colours printing facilities, s scanner and photocopier. There is a small charge for printing and photocopying.
All sites have a 24/7 service where staff may enter the library at any time. There is also self-issue machines, which enable users to issue, renew or return books at any time.
Clinical Librarian Service

Professional staff at Basildon have until recently worked physically closely with Basildon Hospital clinicians in CCU, Colne Ward and Paediatrics providing an evidence and information service at the point of care. This has had to be temporarily withdrawn because of staff shortages and the current pandemic. A similar service at Broomfield linking to burns and plastics has also ceased for the present time. However, staff continue to be able to contact for library for their information needs

Professional staff at Southend have until recently attended weekly ward rounds on Urology and Renal wards, plus regular MDT meetings to provide point of care services and to support teaching at the bedside.
Evidence Searching

Professional staff undertake comprehensive literature searches of a complex nature across authoritative sources and databases to provide good quality evidence-based information to support individual patient care, research, guideline and care pathway development, audit and policy documentation, innovation and quality improvement and CPD for all members of staff upon request, (not undergraduate students). Searching is also undertaken for quality improvement projects and service transformation, in line with the needs of the organization.
Induction and Information Skills Training

Professional staff offer information skills training including searching for evidence and Critical Appraisal, Reflective Writing and Harvard Referencing in different formats (now virtual). Training is also embedded in the training programmes of many student and staff groups. All new staff receive a library welcome email encouraging them to join
Quality Framework

The library until 2021 was required to meet the standards outlined in the NHS Library Quality Assurance Framework (LQAF) - all sites scored 95% or above. From 2021 the new service will be required to submit a baseline assessment for the new HEE NHS Quality and Improvement Outcomes Framework.
Goals
Our goals are aligned to the strategic objectives of MSEFT which are:
Be a single, well-led, high performing and innovative organisation which joins- up care for the people we serve
Deliver high quality, safe and responsive services shaped by best practice and our local communities
Be  an  employer  of  choice  for  a  supported,  engaged  and  high-performing workforce
Be effective and efficient with all our resources, creating an organisation that residents and staff can rely on for the long-term Business Excellence
Our goals are:
To develop into a single, well-led, innovative and responsive service which can adapt to the changing needs of the organisations we serve
To Provide all staff and students access to comfortable and well-equipped, fit for purpose learning environments and places of wellbeing

To provide all staff and students access to the resources and information they need to enhance their personal development, be high performers and deliver the best care and experience for every patient
To deliver an efficient and cost effective service providing value for money for all our stakeholders
To deliver Library and Knowledge services of the highest standard and in line with HEE Knowledge for Healthcare policies and the annual NHS Libraries Quality and Improvement Outcomes Framework
Strategic Objectives
Building a brand and reputation for excellence, within the Trust and across the Mid and South Essex Health Community
We will continue to monitor and evaluate what we do against our specified and published quality measures and service standards in order to maintain and improve services.

We will regularly review the resourcing of the library services in line with the requirements of Health Education England library staffing ratios and the new iteration of the Knowledge for Healthcare which has been recently publishediv.

We will ensure that all library staff receive the appropriate and necessary training, education and support to enable them to develop and deliver excellent services, contributing further to the work of the Trusts and the health of our patients.
We will continually advocate for the inclusion of librarians in meetings/departments at all levels across the Trusts to improve access to the evidence base.

We will market and promote the relevant services and resources for each user group to ensure that all staff/students have access to high quality health care information appropriate to their and their patients' needs.
We will actively pursue opportunities for the growth and development of the service in the form of contracts/ service level agreements with other NHS, social care and affiliated organisations.
We will work closely with all those involved in education and learning to ensure the library meets its responsibilities for the Health Education England Quality Framework.
We will continue to engage with our users through various formal and informal mechanisms to ascertain opinions and make sure that their library, information and knowledge needs are being met.

We will use the  base line submission for the HEE NHS Quality and Improvement Outcomes Framework as a tool to ascertain the direction and strategy of the whole of MSE Healthcare Libraries for the next 5 years.
Developing the physical space of our libraries, providing learning environments that are well equipped and fit for purpose and areas that are conducive to staff wellbeing:
We will oversee the refurbishment and refurnishing of the Broomfield Library site bringing it up to standards required for a 21st century academic library.
We will ensure all sites maintain the required standards for health and safety.
We will ensure all users have access to differing and appropriate areas for study, i.e. group study areas, quiet study areas.
The Library will continue to work closely with the MSEFT IT department to ensure that library computers are fit for use, installed with the most current and appropriate software available.
We will ensure all library users have access to an area for rest and relaxation, including access to appropriate mental health and wellbeing resources as well as those to just relax
We will ensure library staff and users abide by an appropriate code of conduct whilst in the library.

Enhance access to the evidence base by promoting our professional skills and services, developing relationships with individuals and departments across the organisation, both clinical and non-clinical:

We will maintain the excellence of our gold standard literature searching service, searching the literature for individual staff members to answer questions about patient care and safety, audit, quality improvement and developing services to members' deadlines.

We will work to influence the clinical and managerial decision-makers in every profession and every level of the organisation to help to ensure that decisions about quality, innovation, productivity and service development are based on the best available evidence.
We aim to become established as team members of Quality Improvement, audit and research projects providing direct, rapid access to high quality, relevant and accurate resources for such initiatives.
We will continue to provide an appropriate induction to library services and resources, either face to face or virtual, for all staff and students.
We will develop and deliver relevant, tailored courses/ programmes for all levels of staff on request.
We will collaborate with learning, education and development teams in the planning and delivery of courses to ensure that attendees can make the most of library support, training and resources.
We aspire to have information skills training embedded in the training programmes of all staff and students and will continue to build relationships in all areas to bring this about.
The Library will continue to work closely with the MSEFT Communication Department to ensure resources and services are actively promoted through the Trust.
We will contribute to regional and national library technical developments facilitating better access to NHS resources and research findings.

In accordance with HEE Framework 15v and the Knowledge for Healthcare framework (p35) the library will explore how best to engage directly with patients in the areas of health literacy and consumer health information equipping them with the means to access good quality medical and healthcare information to inform their own care.
We will work with individual teams and Patient Information Services in the Trusts to enhance the production and delivery of quality patient information documentation.
We will continue the use of social media, developing library tools for the dissemination of knowledge such as Twitter.
We will continue our work in supporting the creation, storage and accessibility of Trust guidelines.

Enhance access to the evidence base by developing our virtual presence across  the  organisation  and  beyond  enabling  virtual  access to  all  library resources and services across MSE and our partner organisations:
We will use technology to transform access to library services and resources, with the mantra “digital by default”.

We will work with MSEFT Communications Team to develop an external website fit for purpose, enabling all users across MSE and our partner organisations to access resources and services quickly and easily.
We will work with MSEFT and EPUT Communications Teams to ensure all appropriate library information is easily accessible via organisational intranets.
We will ensure library resources can be accessed using mobile technologies, keeping up to date with developments in this field.

We will continue to work collaboratively with the East of England library management system community to develop and implement new and enhanced services to the Regional system for the benefit of all our users.
We will contribute to regional and national library technical developments facilitating better access to NHS resources and research findings.
Purchase the best combination of resources and services to provide value for money for oranisations we serve:
We will comply with the criteria specified in the new Education Contract, in order to be eligible to receive annual funding.
We will continue to work with the Director of Finance to ensure that the library can maintain its delivery of a high-quality library service within budget.
We will cost services to ensure we are providing value for money and to benchmark our services against others in the region.

We will work closely with our stakeholder organisations including EPUT, UCL, QMUL and ARU as well as others whose students use our services (i.e. the University of Essex) to guarantee that all students have access to high quality resources and services appropriate to their needs.
We will collaborate with learning, education (medical and non-medical) and development teams to ensure the library has the correct supporting resources for in-house courses.
We will monitor the Contract to provide knowledge resources and services to EPUT to ensure that all services are provided to standard

We will monitor and evaluate the usage of library resources and aim to strengthen the collection, in line with our Collection Development Policy, so that all professions and specialities are well served.
Monitoring the strategy

This Plan forms the foundation of library endeavour for the next financial year. It sets out the framework by which the Annual Service Plan will be developed and specific developments/activities are decided upon. Plans identify work for the coming year from which individual Team members identify their forthcoming objectives with timescales. The objectives are monitored in each Team members one to one and the overall achievements are recorded in the individual's end of year Appraisal. The Strategic Plan also informs Library Marketing and Training Strategies

The monitoring of the Annual Plan and work arising from it, is also the focus of regular team meetings which are documented as well as continual informal discussion. Library Managers will attend relevant internal meetings such as Medical Education Meetings, Professional and Commissioned Education (PCE) Team Meetings and People & Organisational Development Team meetings to inform stakeholders of the progress of pertinent activities, developments and achievements. Library activity and achievements are reported to the Trust Board. Managers will also be in attendance at relevant external meetings such as the EPUT Workforce development group and at regional Health Libraries network level to report progress with key initiatives
An Annual Report will be produced at the end of the year which will be publicly available on our website and circulated to members of the above meetings,
interested users and stakeholders and senior Trust executives and submitted to the People & OD Committee.
Communication
The strategy will be publicly available on the library websites, as well as on the Trust intranets. Staff will be notified of the new strategy via the various staff bulletins available
Monitoring and audit
Outlined  below  is  the  Trust's  process  of  monitoring  compliance  with,  and  the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / fo rum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
HEE NHS Quality and Improvement Outcomes Framework.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Policy Working Group and Staffside, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the appropriate committees of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 1)
